title: For Sale/Trade:  S&W 1006 10mm Auto
postcontent: For sale or trade, I am offering my S&W Model 1006, a big gosh darned stainless steel automatic in the 10mm Auto caliber -- built like a small, handheld tank. Of the market's current four most popular 10mm pistols (S&W 10 series, Glock 20, EAA Witness, and Colt Delta Elite), this is probably the most durable and, therefore, the best of them all for feeding a regular diet of 10mm Auto of the power scale for which the cartridge was intended. (Although I'm sure that most of the internet would be happy to contend that claim -- please don't yell at me.) Any quick bit of internet research will reveal an unfortunate track record in the case of nearly any of its competitors: the Bren Ten, the gun it was created for, has been made nearly extinct by breakages; the Tanfoglio / EAA Witness is infamous for cracked frames and slides alike and internet forums are littered with tales of owners dealing with its maker's customer service -- some comedy, some tragedy, and some both; manufacturers of both the ammo and the gun itself warn against firing 10mm in a Colt Delta Elite past a certain power level; and even the one real challenger to the 10mm throne, Sir Gaston Glock, has developed with his unsupported chamber a habit of deforming 10mm brass and with his polygonal rifling an inability to utilize cast lead slugs, forcing many of his hand-loading adherents to resort to aftermarket barrels. No such tales of woe have been told about the various S&W offerings and certainly not about the flagship of these, the 1006. (PS, I have not read up much on Sig's recently released P220 10mm -- it's quite possible it is now the best choice for all I know yet. I have heard some ugly things said about SigArms customer service in general, however, so you might want to wait on buying one to be sure all its kinks are worked out. PSS, I have also heard CZ may be developing a CZ 97B in 10mm, which may be everything we all wished the Bren Ten could have been.) But back to the 1006. The 10mm Auto is a cartridge meant to be loaded hot, and this is a pistol meant to thank you for the punishment and ask for more -- as kinky as that sounds. On this subject, I personally recommend the custom ammo brand Underwood and their 180 or 200 grain load going 1350 or 1250 FPS. At 750 foot pounds of energy, that makes this gun a viable provider of protection even out among bear country, especially with those hard cast bullets you can't use in Glocks (though personally I think the best defense against bears is simply to avoid the places dangerous bears tend to hang out). And when exploring the even more dangerous jungle that is man country, this is still as reliable a manstopper as a .41 Magnum in automatic form when loaded with your choice of any advanced hollow point (my recommendation would be Speer's excellent Gold Dot offering, loaded appropriately hot by the aforementioned Underwood). This is a big, heavy beast of a handgun, I'd say about 15-20% bulkier than your standard 1911 of equal length, and its weight makes shooting big, booming, powerhouse loads pure fun. It's also an exceptionally reliable system of bullet-propulsion, relative even to some of the biggest names associated with the word--demonstrably able to cycle unfailingly through not just any ammunition I’ve tried so far, but even an entire magazine full of empty shell casings without a hiccup.If you've never shot one, I can attest that this pistol has at least a decently smooth trigger, about on par with any you'd expect to find on a factory DA/SA Beretta, Sig, or most any other top shelf maker that hasn't had professional trigger work on it, and the one on this example in particular is also very light thanks to an Ed Brown competition hammer spring, which does not appear to have affected its ability to ignite primers in the slightest (though you may want to go back up a few pounds or back to stock anyway if you plan to rely on it for defense, just to be safe). One way in which the triggers of S&W automatics are actually quite exceptional is in the reset; this pistol's is extremely short, as short if not shorter than my 1911 or Sig P210. The only automatic I own with a shorter reset, in fact, is another S&W (a stock, beat to hell $150 Model 59, which has shocked everyone I've shown it to). In fact I strongly recommend that you not hand this pistol with full power ammo to an inexperienced shooter except with an empty magazine, at least for the first time, as the sharp recoil and extremely short reset could have them firing multiple rounds more than they intend to –- a danger for anyone around -- if they don't know what to expect.This is a single-stack handgun, and despite its size its handle is actually exceptionally thin with the stock plastic grips -- thinner than a 1911 -- and I would recommend it to folks who prefer a thinner grip though certainly not to folks with smaller hands or specifically those with shorter fingers, as the trigger and controls do demand a bit of *reach* and despite its thinness, the handle is still quite large. Imagine a 1911 handle flattened by a truck tire is the best I can describe it. Many despise this combination of large yet thin, while some find it perfect for their hand. You would basically have to handle one to know if it is right for you; I suggest you do so, if possible, before committing to buying one. However, when wearing its much thicker *Hogue* grips, it feels no different than most double-stack guns. In fact, for fans of the Beretta M9/92 series, it makes an excellent companion as its controls are nearly identical in function and positioning and, again, when wearing its *Hogue* grips, it has a very similar handle in both width and shape. I imagine this to be the reason the LAPD offered it's .45 ACP cousin, the 4506, as an optional upgrade for officers demanding something heavier hitting than their standard issue 92FS. Update: I have obtained a pair of walnut grips from a Turkish gripmaker that are extremely ergonomic, with a palm swell you'd usually have to look back to the old master gripmakers like Sanderson or Fuzzy Farrant to enjoy. Seriously, these grips have completely changed the feeling of this pistol, from one of my least ergonomic to one of my most. They have taken it for me from a 8 out of 10 gun to a perfect ten in my estimation.Some might disagree with me when I say it is a handsome gun, but I think anyone would agree that it is a gun of considerable, eye-catching *presence,* which has made it or at least its .45-cal twin, the 4506, a favorite of Hollywood -- carried by Sonny Crockett of Miami Vice, Vic Mackey of The Shield, Sam Cole of Robbery Homicide Division, and utilized in a very menacing (if somewhat ridiculous) double akimbo style by Denzel Washington in the film Training Day. In a slightly shorter, slightly reconfigured form -- aka, the 1076 -- this pistol was the official FBI sidearm for several years. It's one of my favorite, most fun handguns to shoot and I wouldn't even consider parting with it except that I now own both a 1076 with documented FBI provenance and a 4505, which is the very rare, very beautiful high gloss blue version of the 4506, and I really don't need three versions of essentially the same gun. This is simply the easiest of the three for me to part with -- as a collector, of course; as a shooter, I imagine I will come to regret parting with this one.These came from the factory with either fixed, slanted Novak low-profile sights or much taller adjustable sights that are ensconced by some unique-looking protective steel "ears," this one being an example of the latter. Interesting fact -- I have read that these ears originated in the Vietnam war, when they were added to the legendary, experimental "Hush Puppy" silenced pistol, which was a heavily modified 39 specially designed for the Navy SEALS, who needed a way to silence guard dogs and other sentries from a distance. The sights had to be raised substantially to clear its silencer, and so the ears were added to keep them from snagging and/or breaking off. If only for this reason alone, even though many despise them, I consider them essential to the trademark "look" of S&W autos.It comes with its original one-piece, super thin plastic grip as well as some alternatives: a palm filling, recoil cushioning Hogue rubber grip; a dressier, fully-checkered Hogue cocobolo grip (which cost $100 new, but feels to me a bit like trying to grip a 2X4); and, depending on how agreeable I find your offer, I may include the pictured Turkish custom grips--which I may also keep to put on the 4505. If they aren't purchased with the gun, I will provide a link to obtain a set of your own, which I strongly, strongly recommend you do. We can also nogtiate on how many magazines I will include -- at least one and a maximum of three. These being S&W factory 9-round magazines with brand new Wolff springs and the upgraded (white) followers. The recoil spring has been upgraded to a 22 pound Wolff spring for shooting full power loads and the hammer spring to an Ed Brown competition 1911 spring for a heavenly double action pull, but I am also including both of the original springs in case you'd rather go stock. For the right trade I may even include a Lou Alessi (one of the best makers in the business) leather shoulder holster for a right handed shooter that also holds two mags on the opposite side.(In summary, currently listed price reflects a puchase of a pistol, one mag, bunch of springs, original grips, hogue rubbers, and hogue wood--possible extras include three extra mags, Alessi holster, KSD grip, two boxes of Underwood 10mm, and potentially even another gun depending on what I'm offered.)Gun is in great shape except for some purely superficial hair thin scratches on the slide only visible in the right light -- inevitable with stainless steel you actually intend to holster and use. I tried to make these visible in the third picture; again, you can only see them if you tilt the pistol just right. Also, the black smudge to the left of the serial number wiped off shortly after I took the picture. The previous owner only shot the watered down Winchester offering and I've shot roughly four boxes of the real stuff (Underwood 180 grain, 1350 FPS) and the pistol shows little to no mechanical wear. Phew. If you've bothered to read all that, I can only assume you're in the market. Make an offer, cash or trade. Worst I can do is not answer -- if I don't have anything to say you'll want to hear, I tend to say nothing at all.
